text:
MPs will debate ​second EU referendum after 4 million sign petition By Leicester Mercury | Posted: July 12, 2016 1 COMMENTS SHARES MPs will debate ​second EU referendum after 4m sign petition MPs will debate ​second EU referendum after 4 million sign petition X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (1) 
Demands from more than four million people for a second referendum on European Union membership will be debated in Parliament. 
MPs said the huge number of signatories to an online petition started by a De Montfort University student meant it was right to set aside time to discuss the calls but warned the move does not signal support for a fresh poll. 
Brexit supporter Oliver Healey, a politics student, launched the petition on the Government's website before the referendum, calling for a new poll if the winning side secures less than 60 per cent of the vote with a lower than 75 per cent turn-out. 
Voters unhappy with the result of the June 23 referendum were quick to back the petition on Parliament's website and more than 4.1 million people have now put their name to it. 
Mr Healey said his petition had then been hijacked by Remain campaigners bidding to overturn the decision in favour of leaving the EU. 
Read more: EU referendum result: How did Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland vote? 
The strongest support for a re-run is in London, with more than 20,000 voters in some constituencies backing the petition. 
A debate will be held in Westminster Hall, the Commons' second chamber, on September 5, opened by the SNP's Ian Blackford. 
Ministers have already formally rejected the demands made in the online request and the Petitions Committee stressed the debate does not have the power to change the law. 
"The committee has decided that the huge number of people signing this petition means that it should be debated by MPs. The Petitions Committee would like to make clear that, in scheduling this debate, they are not supporting the call for a second referendum," a spokesman said. 
"A debate in Westminster Hall does not have the power to change the law, and won't end with the House of Commons deciding whether or not to have a second referendum . 
"Moreover, the petition - which was opened on May 25, well before the referendum - calls for the referendum rules to be changed. It is now too late for the rules to be changed retrospectively. 
"It will be up to the Government to decide whether it wants to start the process of agreeing a new law for a second referendum."
